intro: Diplazium panigrahianum, commonly known as the Panigrahian dichotomous fern, is a species native to the tropical regions of Asia. It belongs to the family Dennstaedtiaceae and is characterized by its distinctive dichotomous branching pattern in both its fronds and rhizomes. The plant produces small, inconspicuous spore-bearing structures called sori, which are typically located on the underside of the fronds. Diplazium panigrahianum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forests and rocky crevices. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an interesting subject for botanical study.
